I'm voting to finally recognize that most basic right: the right to strike. The basis of all labor power.

6/6

All working people deserve safe jobs, a living wage, and time to care for loved ones. But far too many are still living paycheck to paycheck while greedy corporations divide us up, hoping we’ll look the other way while they reap the profits from our hard work.

5/

The labor movement of the first half of the 20th Century laid the groundwork for prosperity and the most powerful economy in the world. 

All the while, big business has sought to undermine and sabotage their efforts, often illegally.

4/

Workers built this country from the ground up. What we have today is the result of their hard work. For too long they've been denied their right to come together to level the playing field and demand a shot at a good life.

3/

Workers of all backgrounds join together in unions. They fight for better hours, better pay, and safe working conditions. 

Union struggles have brought us the 40-hour work week and the 8-hour day, the weekend, the end of child labor, unemployment benefits...

2/

1/

We all want to get there as soon as possible. But that starts with the steps we take right now to support and listen to public health experts about how we end this pandemic, and working with them to get all of our communities there.

This pandemic will not truly be over until we vaccinate everyone we can. And even when it ends, we need to make sure nothing like this happens ever again—which is why I’m reintroducing critical public health infrastructure legislation later this week.

We’re all well aware that it’s not “mission accomplished.”

We have to roll up our sleeves, literally and figuratively, and get vaccines in arms.

We took a critical step toward making that a reality by passing the American Rescue Plan, which includes funding for 
✅bolstering COVID testing, contact tracing, & sequencing 
✅increasing vaccines distribution & administration 
✅addressing health inequities 
And so much more.

And it should be just as unthinkable that we would do anything short of everything when it comes to ending this crisis as soon as possible and rebuilding our nation stronger and fairer. I’m glad @POTUS has put forward a bold vision to see our country through this pandemic.

We are all familiar with the staggering numbers of this pandemic—29 million infected and over half a million dead. But the full toll of that loss and what families have gone through cannot be measured.

The true cost of this pandemic so far is unthinkable.

JOIN ME LIVE as I chair today’s HELP Committee hearing on the ongoing response to the COVID-19 pandemic, with witnesses from the frontlines of our fight against this virus. https://twitter.com/i/broadcasts/1rmGPzqEWOjxN
